text: The psychological muscle you have to build to be a great leader is to be able to click in the abyss and go, 'Okay, that way's slightly better. We're going to go that way. If everybody agrees with the decision, then you didn't add any value because they would've done that without you.' So the only value you ever add is when you make a decision that most people don't like.
speaker: Ben Horowitz
context: Lenny asks Ben about the difficulty and pain of being a CEO and why so many people still want to start companies despite this reality. Ben explains that leaders must develop the psychological strength to make extremely difficult decisions where all options appear terrible. He emphasizes that true leadership value comes from making unpopular but necessary decisions that others wouldn't make on their own.
text_ko: 훌륭한 리더가 되려면 심리적 근육(psychological muscle)을 길러야 해요. 깊은 불확실성 속에서도 딱 결정을 내려서 “음, 저쪽이 조금 더 낫네요. 그쪽으로 가겠습니다”라고 말할 수 있어야 해요. 만약 모두가 그 결정에 동의했다면 당신은 아무런 가치를 더한 게 아니에요—그 사람들이 당신 없이도 그렇게 했을 테니까요. 그래서 리더로서 진짜 가치를 만드는 건 대부분의 사람들이 좋아하지 않는 결정을 내릴 때뿐이에요.
text_zh: 要成为优秀领导者，你得练就一种心理素质——就是在一片迷茫中还能拍板："好，那个方向稍微好一点，咱们就往那边走。"如果所有人都同意你的决定，那说明你其实没创造什么价值，因为没有你他们也会这么做。所以你真正的价值就体现在——当你做出大多数人都不太认同的决定时。
text_es: El músculo psicológico que tienes que desarrollar para ser un gran líder es poder quedarte ahí en el abismo y decir: "Bueno, por ahí se ve un poquito mejor. Vamos por ese lado." Si todo el mundo está de acuerdo con tu decisión, entonces no aportaste nada porque lo habrían hecho sin ti. Así que el único valor que realmente agregas es cuando tomas una decisión que a la mayoría no le gusta.
key_sentence: You didn't add any value if everyone agrees with your decision.

text: What I was trying to get out in Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager, was the job is fundamentally a leadership job. And it's a tricky leadership job because nobody is actually reporting to you.
speaker: Ben Horowitz
context: Lenny mentions Ben's famous piece 'Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager' and asks about its relevance today. Ben explains that when he wrote this internal document at Netscape, he was trying to help product managers understand that their role is primarily about leadership, not just completing tasks like writing specs or conducting interviews. The challenge is that PMs must lead without having direct authority over the people they need to influence.
text_ko: 제가 'Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager'에서 말하려던 건, 프로덕트 매니저(Product Manager)라는 직무가 근본적으로 리더십 역할(leadership job)이라는 거예요. 그리고 이건 까다로운 리더십 역할인데, 그 이유는 실제로 아무도 당신에게 직접 보고하지 않기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 我在《好的产品经理，坏的产品经理》里想说的是，这个岗位本质上就是个领导职位。而且这个领导职位特别有挑战性，因为实际上没有人直接向你汇报。
text_es: Lo que trataba de transmitir en "Good Product Manager, Bad Product Manager" es que el trabajo es fundamentalmente un puesto de liderazgo. Y es un liderazgo complicado porque en realidad nadie te reporta directamente.
key_sentence: It's a tricky leadership job with no one reporting to you.

text: Probably one of my bigger ones on that was we went public with $2 million in trailing 12 months revenue at 18 months old. That's obviously a bad idea. But the truth of it was the alternative was going bankrupt, and that's a worse idea.
speaker: Ben Horowitz
context: Ben is discussing the importance of running towards fear and making difficult decisions as a leader, even when both available options seem terrible. He shares a personal example from his CEO experience where he had to choose between two bad alternatives. Ben explains that hesitation is the worst thing a leader can do, and sometimes you must choose the less terrible option even when it will result in harsh criticism.
text_ko: 그와 관련해 제가 저지른 큰 실수 중 하나는 설립한 지 18개월밖에 안 됐을 때 최근 12개월 매출(trailing 12 months revenue)이 200만 달러인 상태로 상장했다는 거예요. 분명히 그건 안 좋은 결정이었어요. 그런데 사실 다른 선택지는 파산하는 것뿐이었고, 그건 더 나쁜 선택이었어요.
text_zh: 我犯的比较大的错误之一就是，公司才18个月大的时候我们就上市了，当时过去12个月的收入才200万美元。这明显是个糟糕的决定。但实话说，当时要么这样，要么破产，破产显然更糟糕。
text_es: Probablemente uno de mis errores más grandes fue que salimos a bolsa con solo 2 millones de dólares en ingresos de los últimos 12 meses cuando la empresa tenía apenas 18 meses. Obviamente es una pésima idea. Pero la realidad era que la alternativa era quebrar, y eso es aún peor.
key_sentence: Trailing 12 months revenue at $2 million was a bad idea, worse than going bankrupt.

text: The only reason to start a company is because you have an irrational desire to do so, because it's not worth the money. So I think if you're doing it for the money, that's a very bad reason and it will be extremely difficult to get you an outcome.
speaker: Ben Horowitz
context: Lenny asks Ben who should not start companies and what advice he gives to people considering entrepreneurship who may not understand what they're getting into. Ben shares wisdom from John Reed, former CEO of Citigroup, about the true motivation needed for starting a company. He emphasizes that founders need a deeper purpose beyond financial gain to survive the inevitable challenges of building a company.
text_ko: 창업을 하는 유일한 이유는 그걸 하고 싶다는 비합리적인 열망이 있어서예요. 돈 때문에 할 일은 아니거든요. 돈을 목적으로 한다면 그건 아주 나쁜 이유이고 원하는 성과를 얻기 굉장히 어려울 거예요.
text_zh: 创业的唯一理由就是你有一种说不上来的冲动想去做这件事，因为单纯为了赚钱的话根本不值得。所以我觉得如果你是冲着钱去的，那动机就很有问题，最后也很难有什么好结果。
text_es: La única razón para montar una empresa es porque tienes unas ganas irracionales de hacerlo, porque por la plata no vale la pena. Así que creo que si lo haces por el dinero, es una razón muy mala y va a ser súper difícil que logres buenos resultados.
key_sentence: An irrational desire to start a company is essential to get you an outcome.

text: You don't make people great. You find people that make you great, that make the company great, that you learned from, not the other way around. What's leverage is if you're telling me what you should do and how you can push the company forward, that's leverage, then I'm getting more than I'd have if you weren't there.
speaker: Ben Horowitz
context: Lenny shares a story from Ali Ghodsi (CEO of Databricks) about advice Ben gave him when he became CEO regarding low performers on his team. Ben explains the concept of 'managerial leverage' - the difference between spending time developing people versus finding people who can drive the company forward independently. He emphasizes that as a CEO, you should focus on hiring people who can teach you and push the company forward, rather than trying to coach people in areas where you lack expertise.
text_ko: 사람을 훌륭하게 만드는 건 당신이 아니에요. 대신 당신이 할 일은 당신을 훌륭하게 만드는 사람들, 회사를 훌륭하게 만드는 사람들, 그리고 당신이 배울 사람들을 찾아내는 거예요. 그 반대가 아니에요. 진짜 레버리지(leverage)는 당신이 뭘 해야 하는지, 어떻게 회사를 앞으로 이끌어갈 수 있는지 제게 말해주는 사람이에요. 그게 레버리지예요. 그러면 당신이 없었더라면 못 얻었을 더 많은 가치를 제가 얻게 되는 거죠.
text_zh: 你不是去培养牛人，而是要找到那些能让你变牛、让公司变牛的人，你要从他们身上学东西，而不是反过来。真正的杠杆效应(leverage)是什么？就是你能告诉我该怎么做，怎么推动公司往前走，这才叫杠杆效应，这样我得到的价值比没有你的时候要大得多。
text_es: No haces grande a la gente. Encuentras a personas que te hacen grande a ti, que hacen grande a la empresa, personas de las que tú aprendes, no al revés. Lo que realmente tiene valor es cuando tú me dices qué deberíamos hacer y cómo puedes impulsar la empresa hacia adelante, eso sí es apalancamiento (leverage), ahí es cuando obtengo más de lo que tendría si tú no estuvieras.
key_sentence: Managerial leverage comes from finding people who push the company forward.

text: There's a very consistent thing that happens, which is when somebody doesn't make it and it kind of starts with confidence is the way I would put it. And then if you lose confidence, what happens is you hesitate on the next decision.
speaker: Ben Horowitz
context: Lenny asks Ben when it actually makes sense to replace a founder as CEO, flipping the question about A16Z's philosophy of helping founders stay in their roles. Ben explains the pattern he's observed when founders fail as CEOs. He describes how the natural mistakes that come with learning to run a company can lead to a loss of confidence, which then creates hesitation in decision-making, ultimately leading to organizational dysfunction.
text_ko: 항상 비슷한 일이 생겨요. 누군가 잘 안 되기 시작하면, 제 표현대로라면 그건 자신감에서부터 시작돼요. 자신감을 잃으면 다음 결정을 내릴 때 주저하게 돼요.
text_zh: 有个很常见的现象，就是当有人做不成事的时候，我觉得根源往往是自信心出了问题。一旦失去自信，接下来做决定的时候就会犹豫不决。
text_es: Hay algo que pasa de manera muy consistente, y es cuando alguien no la logra, y yo diría que todo empieza con el tema de la confianza. Y luego, si pierdes la confianza, lo que pasa es que dudas en la siguiente decisión.
key_sentence: Losing confidence means you hesitate on the next decision.

text: I think the thing that's right about what Sam is saying is the landscape is early, really early. The technology is very immature. As amazingly as it works, there's a long way to go to improve it. So it's very possible when you have that much technological change, that the positions that these companies have achieved with their high revenue isn't sustainable.
speaker: Ben Horowitz
context: Lenny asks Ben about the potential AI bubble, referencing Sam Altman's recent comments that 'we're in a big bubble.' Ben analyzes Sam's statement, first noting that it's strategically smart for Sam to say this as a CEO. He then gives his perspective on whether AI is actually in a bubble, explaining that while he doesn't think it's a financial bubble like the dot-com era, there could be competitive disruption due to the immaturity of the technology.
text_ko: 샘이 말한 것 중 맞는 건 지금 시장 환경(landscape)이 초기 단계라는 거예요. 정말 초반이에요. 기술(technology)은 아직 많이 미성숙해요. 놀랍게도 잘 작동하긴 하지만 개선할 부분이 훨씬 많아요. 그래서 기술 변화가 그만큼 크면 이 회사들이 높은 매출로 차지한 위치가 오래 유지되기 힘들 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得Sam说得对的地方在于，这个赛道还很早期，真的是非常早期。技术还很不成熟。虽然现在效果已经很惊人了，但要改进的地方还有很多很多。所以当技术变化这么大的时候，这些公司现在凭借高营收占据的位置很可能是站不住脚的。
text_es: Creo que Sam tiene razón en algo: estamos en las primeras etapas, muy temprano todavía. La tecnología está muy verde aún. Por más increíble que funcione, le falta un mundo por mejorar. Entonces es muy probable que con tantos cambios tecnológicos, las posiciones que han logrado estas empresas con sus altos ingresos no sean sostenibles a largo plazo.
key_sentence: The landscape is early, and high revenue positions aren't sustainable.
